page_analysis.text_content:
Height & grade

Height

Max. height
to roof peak

Structure

Main dwelling on a standard lot
with a roof slope <12:12
30'

Main dwelling on a standard lot
with a roof slope ≥12:12
33'

Main dwelling on a substandard
or flag lot
17'

Accessory structure in rear or
side yard
12'

2nd-dwelling units
17'

Fig 43 Determining slope of roof

12" run
6" rise

Roof slope is the vertical rise in inches for every horizontal distance of twelve inches (called the "run"). It is expressed as rise:run or, in this example 6:12.

Note: On a drawing this slope might also be represented as:
6 12 or 1 2

Fig 42 Comparison of roof slopes

Height measured to top of roof material

33'
30'

12 : 14
12 : 12
12 : 10
12 : 6
12 : 3

Height limit = 33'
Height limit = 30'

Height allowances enable a variety of architectural styles while preserving the residential scale of our neighborhoods as well as the privacy and natural light available to each lot.

Code sections
Page 46
18.12.040 (a) Table 2
Page 47
18.04.030 (64) (b)

46

visual_elements.description: Table listing structure types and their maximum height to roof peak. Includes: Main dwelling on a standard lot with roof slope <12:12 (30'), with roof slope ≥12:12 (33'), main dwelling on substandard or flag lot (17'), accessory structure in rear or side yard (12'), and 2nd-dwelling units (17').

Diagram titled 'Fig 43 Determining slope of roof' showing a roof edge with a horizontal run of 12 inches and a vertical rise of 6 inches, illustrating how roof slope is calculated as rise:run (6:12). Also shows alternative slope representations as fractions: 6/12 or 1/2.

Fig 42 Comparison of roof slopes: Five stylized house roof shapes with different slopes labeled 12:14, 12:12, 12:10, 12:6, and 12:3. Two horizontal lines above indicate height limits of 33' and 30'. The first two slopes (12:14 and 12:12) correspond to a height limit of 33', while the last three slopes correspond to a height limit of 30'.

Vertical sidebar on left side with heading 'Height & grade' and descriptive text about height allowances enabling architectural styles while preserving residential scale, privacy, and natural light. Also includes code section references for pages 46 and 47.

technical_specifications.parameter: Max. height to roof peak for main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope <12:12
Max. height to roof peak for main dwelling on a standard lot with a roof slope ≥12:12
Max. height to roof peak for main dwelling on a substandard or flag lot
Max. height to roof peak for accessory structure in rear or side yard
Max. height to roof peak for 2nd-dwelling units
Height limit for roof slopes 12:14 and 12:12
Height limit for roof slopes 12:10, 12:6, and 12:3

additional_notes: Page number 46 at bottom left corner.
Code section references: Page 46 (18.12.040 (a) Table 2) and Page 47 (18.04.030 (64) (b)).
No handwritten annotations or stamps detected.
Text and diagrams are clear and legible.

conditions.text: Max. height to roof peak for main dwelling on a substandard or flag lot = 17'
Max. height to roof peak for accessory structure in rear or side yard = 12'
Max. height to roof peak for 2nd-dwelling units = 17'

logical_relationships.expression: If roof slope <12:12 then max height to roof peak = 30'
If roof slope ≥12:12 then max height to roof peak = 33'

execution_sequence.action: Determine roof slope and compare to 12:12
If roof slope <12:12, apply max height to roof peak = 30'
If roof slope ≥12:12, apply max height to roof peak = 33'
